headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of March 12, 2019

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions Against  Venezuelan-Russian Bank
summary: The U.S. government accused Moscow-based Evrofinance Mosnarbank of facilitating illicit transactions to benefit the regime of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro.

headline: White House Proposes $4.7 Trillion Budget for Fiscal 2020
summary: The White House released a $4.7 trillion budget that proposed sharply reducing spending on safety-net programs, while boosting defense and border-protection funding.

headline: Trump Keeps the Pressure on State Department Spending
summary: President Trump wants to cut 23% of State Department and international-program  spending next year, drawing criticism from retired military officials and the Democrats who control the House.

headline: Nonprofit AI Lab Alters Structure to Build Massive Computing Power
summary: The team running OpenAI is opening a new chapter. In its next act, it may end up looking more like a traditional startup—but with a structural twist that speaks to its ideals of using AI for the public good while guarding against the technology doing harm.

headline: Google Agreed to Pay $135 Million to Two Executives Accused of Sexual Harassment
summary: Google agreed to pay $135 million in exit packages to two top executives who left the company after being accused of sexual harassment and covered up the reasons for their departures.

headline: Care.com Overhauls Vetting of Sitters, Listings
summary: Care.com, the country’s largest marketplace for babysitters and other caregivers, unveiled a set of policies aimed at overseeing its members and said it had taken steps to remove fake day-care center listings.

headline: Powell: Revisions to Community Reinvestment Act Implementation Must ‘Strengthen’ Law’s Mission
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said he was supportive of regulators’ continuing efforts to improve the way they implement a 1977 law that requires federally insured banks to promote lending to borrowers in low- and moderate-income areas.

headline: AT&T Executives’ Pay Climbed After Media Takeover
summary: AT&T Chief Executive Randall Stephenson’s total compensation edged up to more than $29 million last year while his lieutenants received hefty bonuses tied to the company’s acquisition of Time Warner.

headline: Boeing’s 737 MAX Keeps Flying, but Some Passengers Are Staying on the Ground
summary: Following the Ethiopian Airlines crash, some skittish travelers are checking their tickets to see if they are scheduled to fly on a Boeing 737 MAX and asking airlines to allow them to change.

headline: A Boeing Pacesetter, the 737, Confronts Trying Times
summary: Boeing achieved another milestone last year, snagging the Guinness world record for most-produced plane model with its 737 single-aisle jet. Now the company faces one of the program’s most challenging periods.

headline: Iranian Court Sentences U.S. Navy Veteran, Human-Rights Lawyer
summary: An Iranian court has sentenced a U.S. Navy veteran for an unspecified crime, according to Iranian state-linked media, in a move that threatens to further strain relations between Washington and Tehran.

headline: Boies Is Dealt Setback in Venezuela Oil Conspiracy Lawsuit
summary: A U.S. judge threw out a lawsuit brought by famed lawyer David Boies on behalf of Venezuela’s state energy company that alleged bid-rigging by oil traders.

headline: Trump’s Pentagon Budget War
summary: Tax revenues are expected to rise but spending will rise faster.

headline: Democrats Want Milwaukee’s Finest
summary: The 2020 convention in Wisconsin is billed as ‘a statement of our values’

headline: The Black Robe New Deal
summary: Democrats float packing the Supreme Court if they win in 2020.

headline: Tesla, in Reversal, to Keep More Stores Open
summary: Electric-car maker Tesla said it would keep more showrooms open than it had previously planned, and that it would also raise its vehicle prices by about 3% on average world-wide.

headline: The Case for Joe Biden
summary: The former vice president could pose a formidable challenge to Trump—if Democrats let him.

headline: Ilhan Omar Can’t Break the U.S.-Israel Bond
summary: Don’t be afraid of her silly theories about ‘the Benjamins’ and the Jews.

headline: U.N. Remembers Victims of Ethiopian Airlines Crash
summary: Flags flew at half-staff and meetings began with moments of silence across the United Nations as workers and officials memorialized the 21 staff members of the world body killed in the Ethiopian Airlines crash.

headline: ‘King Kong’ Can’t Get a Grip on Broadway
summary: The Broadway musical “King Kong” has seen its grosses plummet in recent weeks, according to figures from the Broadway League.

headline: ‘Love Your Enemies’ Review: Let’s Agree to Disagree
summary: Anger isn’t ruining our politics. Contempt—that dismissive attitude we hold against those who don’t share our views—is the bigger danger.

headline: Little Red Hen vs. Blue-State Lawmakers
summary: For economic lessons, read children’s fairy tales and ignore socialist ones.

headline: Around Jackson Documentary, Airplay Is Down, Streaming Is Up
summary: Amid HBO’s release of a documentary accusing Michael Jackson of sexually abusing boys, consumers have been listening to more of the late pop star’s music, while radio programmers have been playing it less.

headline: American Capitalism Is Fine, Thank You
summary: The real debate is whether to accept the creative destruction at the heart of the free-market system.

headline: Solitary Confinement Helps Control Prison Gangs
summary: Reformers demand its abolition, but there are precious few effective alternatives.

headline: How the British Hit Back Against Russian Agitprop
summary: The Kremlin loves using disinformation to sow chaos. Deterrence requires a plan for a second strike.

headline: Pelosi Opposes Pursuing Impeachment of Trump
summary: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said she doesn’t support pursuing the impeachment of President Trump, saying such a step would be too divisive and the Democratic Party should focus on winning back the White House in 2020.

headline: Hospitals, Insurers Set to Resist Price Transparency Proposal
summary: Hospitals and insurers are gearing up to battlethat could require the public disclosure of negotiated prices for medical services, part of an effort to lower U.S. health-care costs.

headline: New York City School Menus Go Meatless on Mondays
summary: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced all city public schools will officially have “Meatless Monday,” starting next fall, a move he said will improve the health of children and the planet.

headline: Bipartisan Bill Pushes for Emergency Plan for Hudson Rail Tunnel
summary: New York and New Jersey lawmakers introduced federal legislation requiring the Trump administration to develop an emergency plan if a critical rail tunnel between the two states must undergo repairs before a replacement opens.

headline: Algeria’s President Won’t Seek Fifth Term After Protests
summary: Ailing Algerian President Abdelaziz Bouteflika said he won’t seek a fifth term in power, bowing to popular pressure after widespread protests shook the North African nation.

headline: New Display Technologies Set to Transform Workspaces
summary: In the years ahead, it will be more common for workspaces to host multiple monitors of all kinds, including computer and tablet screens and displays that facilitate augmented and virtual reality experiences.

headline: At Hudson Yards, Stunning Views From on High
summary: The supertall 30 Hudson Yards—New York’s third-tallest building—now offers the best view of the city out there, but its outdoor public spaces leave much to be desired.

headline: Boeing Shares Slide More Than 5% After Airline Crash
summary: Shares of Boeing Co. tumbled more than 5% on Monday, a day after the deadly Ethiopian Airlines crash, the biggest drop in the plane maker’s stock in more than four months.

headline: U.S. Hedge Fund to Offer Its Own Slate of Directors for Toshiba
summary: New York-based hedge fund King Street Capital Management said it intends to nominate a slate of independent directors to replace a majority of Toshiba’s board.

headline: U.S. Places Sanctions on Moscow-Based Evrofinance Mosnarbank
summary: The bank, which is jointly owned by Russian and Venezuelan state entities, has assisted and provided support for Venezuela state-owned oil giant Petróleos de Venezuela SA, or PdVSA, which has been on the U.S. sanctions list since January, the Treasury said.

headline: KPMG Ex-Partner Convicted In ‘Steal the Exam’ Scandal
summary: A former high-ranking partner at KPMG was convicted on accusations he was involved in a scheme to steal confidential information.

headline: Dollar Inches Down on Economic Worries
summary: The dollar edged lower Monday, after a weak employment report stoked concerns of slowing U.S. growth.

headline: An Earnings Climb Buys Stitch Fix Time
summary: Stitch Fix shares surged in large part because of excessive skepticism about its business, not clear evidence that its business model is healthy.

headline: Budget Proposal Adds Funding for Fighting HIV/AIDS in U.S., Cuts Contribution to Global Effort
summary: The president’s proposed budget included new funding for his push to end the epidemic of the virus that causes AIDS in the U.S. by 2030, but it also laid out big cuts to the nation’s role in the global fight against the epidemic.

headline: Sporting-Goods Retailer Modell’s Hires Restructuring Adviser
summary: The New York-based retailer, which has more than 150 stores in the Northeast, has hired Berkeley Research Group as its financial adviser to explore its next steps, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: ‘American Football’ Review: More Than Moody
summary: The new self-titled album from a pioneering band revived by its cult following is the group’s most ethereal, atmospheric release yet.

headline: Tesla Reaches Deal With Lenders in China
summary: The electric-car maker said a syndicate of lenders agreed to invest as much as $521 million in its factory in Shanghai.

headline: Immigration-Enforcement Staff Would Grow Under Budget Proposal
summary: The Trump administration wants to add 100 new judges, 300 attorneys and 200 support staff to handle the massive backlog of immigration cases.

headline: Running for Justice After 30 Years Wrongfully Behind Bars
summary: A man who was wrongly incarcerated for 30 years and exonerated by the Innocence Project will celebrate his freedom by running a half-marathon in New York City.

headline: Trump Administration Proposes 14% Cut to Interior Department
summary: Under the Trump budget for the Interior Department, spending on the National Park Service would fall 14%, while funds for the Bureau of Reclamation, which oversees irrigation, would drop 31%.

headline: Neiman Marcus Bondholder Makes Counteroffer to Proposed Debt Deal
summary: Neiman Marcus Group Ltd. bondholder Marble Ridge Capital has reached out to the luxury retailer with an offer to extend the company’s debt maturities by two years, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Iran Seeks Help From Iraq to Defy U.S. Sanctions
summary: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani is seeking to boost economic links with Iraq on his first official visit to the neighboring country, at a time when the U.S. is upping efforts to curb Tehran’s regional influence.

headline: Military Budget Would Rise by $33 Billion
summary: The White House is proposing a budget of nearly $720 billion for the Pentagon for fiscal 2020, adding $33 billion to fund efforts against China and Russia, rogue states such as North Korea and Iran, and to fight Islamic State and other militants.

headline: Raise Taxes to Raise Social Security Benefits
summary: Congressman Larson replies to the Journal’s editorial on his Social Security 2100 Act.

headline: Oregon Planners Know Best on Urban Sprawl
summary: Portland’s land-use rules prevent the ugliness of most American suburbs.

headline: Mr. Hickenlooper’s Electoral College Vote Conundrum
summary: Legislation awaits his Democratic successor’s signature to “fix” our 18th-century Electoral College that would give our state’s nine votes away to the national popular-vote winner.

headline: Treat Opioid Money Better Than Past Cigarette Funds
summary: The state of Connecticut has collected approximately $2.5 billion in tobacco settlement funds over the past 20 years and has spent virtually nothing of those funds on smoking-cessation programs or other smoking/health-related programs.

headline: The MLB Coach Who Played Only T-Ball
summary: Jonathan Erlichman hasn’t played baseball since the age of 5. But he is now the first full-time analytics coach ever to join a major-league staff.

headline: White House Proposes to Cut Labor Department Funding by Nearly 10%
summary: The White House proposed a $1.2 billion, or 9.7%, decrease in funding for the Labor Department in the 2020 fiscal year.

headline: Treasurys Edge Lower As Investors Remain Wary
summary: U.S. government bond prices edged lower Monday, keeping yields within their recent narrow range as investors monitor global political and economic developments.

headline: Russia’s Economic Clout in Europe Grows Despite Sanctions, Study Says
summary: Russia is taking advantage of opaque corporate registration laws, permissive tax environments and uneven anticorruption practices to expand its economic footprint in Western Europe despite U.S. and European sanctions, according to a new report.

headline: Do You Want to Trade Futures? ‘Micro’ Contracts May Make It Easier
summary: Exchange giant CME hopes to draw more retail investors into trading futures with a plan to launch new, bite-sized contracts linked to U.S. stock indexes.

headline: Trump Budget Would Boost Spending on Veterans
summary: The Trump administration’s proposed budget for fiscal 2020 would increase funding for the Department of Veterans Affairs, including a nearly 10% boost for medical care.

headline: Farmers Take a Hit in President’s Draft Budget
summary: A Trump administration proposal to cut Agriculture Department funding by 15% drew consternation from growers and ranchers who are struggling through a multiyear slump in the U.S. farm economy.

headline: Oil Climbs on Signs Saudi Output Cuts Could Be Extended
summary: Oil prices rose, supported by signs that aggressive OPEC production cuts are rebalancing an oversupplied market despite worries that demand will crumble.

headline: Zinedine Zidane Is Back at Real Madrid
summary: With Real Madrid in the midst of its most chaotic season in recent memory, Zinedine Zidane is returning to the sideline after stepping down as manager 10 months ago

headline: U.K. to Launch New Audit and Accounting Regulator
summary: The U.K. watchdog that oversees accounting and auditing firms will be folded into a new regulator called the Audit, Reporting and Governance Authority, a move aimed at boosting the quality of a crucial industry as the country heads for its exit from the European Union.

headline: Budget Request Cuts Funds for Health and Human Services
summary: The president’s budget requests $87.1 billion for the Department of Health and Human Services, a 12% drop from the estimated 2019 level.

headline: EPA Budget Would Be Slashed by 31%
summary: The administration is proposing slashing the Environmental Protection Agency’s budget by 31%, to $6.1 billion, in keeping with its previous requests to shrink the agency.

headline: Peer Pressure Can Improve Your Financial Life, Study Finds
summary: How do you get people to make better financial decisions? Peer pressure can help, according to new research by three economists.

headline: European Creditors Freeze Funds for Greece as Overhauls Stall
summary: Eurozone finance ministers delayed the release of €1 billion ($1.12 billion) of funding for Greece, in a sign of European concern that Athens is backing away from promised economic overhauls as elections approach.

headline: Drop In February Inflation Expectations, N.Y. Fed Report Says
summary: Nearly a year’s worth of stability in the public’s inflation expectations gave way in February, raising questions about the future of price pressures and further boosting doubt over the prospect of more Federal Reserve rate rises.

headline: Education Budget Proposal Highlights Vouchers, Vocational Training
summary: The Trump administration’s budget proposes cuts in the Education Department’s funding, while emphasizing workforce training and a mechanism to curb college costs.

headline: Transportation Budget Focuses on Incentive Grants, Amtrak Shift
summary: The Trump administration’s budget proposes sharp cuts in discretionary spending at the Transportation Department next year, and continues the administration’s efforts to use federal grants to reward cities and states that raise their own revenues to fund infrastructure building

headline: Nvidia Plays All of Its Chips
summary: The chip maker’s first big M&A deal comes when Nvidia needs it the most.

headline: When Your Houseguests Can Buy Everything They See
summary: Contemporary design gallerist David Alhadeff, who founded the Future Perfect in 2003, has filled a West Village townhouse with his company’s wares, from sculptures to towels. He’s also living there—and inviting customers to drop by.

headline: Play Barbie, Earn Free Nights
summary: For Barbie’s 60th anniversary, a Hilton hotel in Mexico City offers guests a chance to go glamping like the doll.

headline: Woman Accused of Killing Kim Jong Un’s Half-Brother Walks Free
summary: A Malaysian court freed an Indonesian woman who was accused of playing a role in the killing of the half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

headline: Democrats Choose Milwaukee for 2020 National Convention
summary: The Democratic Party has selected Milwaukee to hold its 2020 national convention, choosing to nominate its challenger to President Trump in the key battleground state of Wisconsin.

headline: Owner of Revlon Hair Dryers, Pert Shampoo Looks to Exit Some Beauty Brands
summary: The maker of Revlon hair dryers and Pert shampoo has put part of its beauty business up for sale.

headline: A Really Bad Retail Sales Report
summary: The January retail sales report wasn’t just less strong than it appeared; it was downright weak.

headline: Super Bowl? Try a Superyacht, the Hot Luxury Buy for NFL Billionaires
summary: Since the start of the year, there has been a showy wave of NFL owner superyacht acquisition, to the point it appears to be a league trend, writes columnist Jason Gay.

headline: CTI Foods Files $406 Million Debt-Cutting Bankruptcy
summary: Private equity-backed food supplier CTI Foods entered chapter 11 bankruptcy Monday with plans for a quick exit that would turn its top lenders into owners while cutting $406 million in debt off the company’s books.

headline: Dating 101, for the Romantically Challenged Gen Z
summary: Educators say the current generation of college students is uniquely bad at dating. One professor is taking matters into her own hands.

headline: Retail Sales Rose Modestly in January
summary: Consumer spending recovered only modestly at the start of the year, signaling a slowdown in economic growth between the fourth and first quarters.

headline: Boeing Investors Need History Lesson After Crash
summary: Investors dumped Boeing stock after Sunday’s deadly plane crash. But the lesson of history is that such accidents, however tragic, do surprisingly little damage to the business of selling aircraft.

headline: Stocks to Watch: Boeing, Nvidia, Barrick Gold, Apple, GE
summary: Boeing, Nvidia, Mellanox Technologies, Barrick Gold, Apple and GE are among Monday’s stocks to watch.

headline: Second Wave of U.S. Shale Revolution Is Coming, Says IEA
summary: The U.S. is on track to become a net petroleum exporter by 2021 and will soon after surpass Russia and rival Saudi Arabia, according to the International Energy Agency.

headline: Scores Killed in Ethiopian Airlines Jet Crash
summary: An Ethiopian Airlines Boeing 737 MAX 8 crashed en route from Addis Ababa to Nairobi, killing all 157 aboard including eight Americans and 18 Canadians.

headline: Do Democrats Hear Echoes of 1972 Today?
summary: The Democratic Party’s turn to the left after Nixon’s victory led to electoral disaster. Similarities and differences can be seen in the runup to 2020.

headline: Deutsche Bank’s Arranged Marriage Gets Shove From ECB
summary: Success is a mixture of being good and being lucky. Whatever you think about management at Deutsche Bank, luck isn’t on its side.

headline: Touring Casa Perfect
summary: The Future Perfect opens a townhouse in New York’s West Village

headline: Fighting Breast Cancer Without Surgery
summary: Breast-cancer patients are joining trials to see if they can skip surgery altogether—a less-invasive approach that would be a milestone in treatment.

headline: California Weighs Overhauling Utility Regulator
summary: California Gov. Gavin Newsom is considering replacing the head of the state Public Utilities Commission and overhauling the body in the wake of PG&E's bankruptcy as he and other leaders prepare for another wildfire season.

headline: Brooklyn Botanic Garden Resists Buildings That Would Cast Shade
summary: As spring approaches, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden fears a new neighbor could leave it in the shadows.

headline: Investors Are Winning More Treasury Auctions
summary: Demand for government bonds is growing as investors weigh the Fed’s next interest-rate moves. Domestic investors purchased a record of roughly 55% of the new U.S. government notes and bonds sold at auction in January.

headline: Life After Ghosn: Renault, Nissan Seek to Patch Up Alliance
summary: The Renault-Nissan alliance is set to get a new decision-making body, replacing a structure established by the architect of the partnership, former Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn.

headline: Chinese Central Bank’s Rhetoric Is Concerning
summary: Disagreements over Chinese economic policy have been unusually obvious lately. Two bits of news suggest the uncertainty is affecting monetary policy.

headline: How Kraft Heinz Ate Its Seed Corn
summary: Kraft Heinz is paying the price now for slashing spending on research and development.

headline: After Near-Win in 2018, Democrats Hope to Flip Texas Blue
summary: Several of the party’s presidential candidates visited Texas over the weekend as they look to turn the red state blue in 2020.

headline: U.S. Bulks Up Ukraine’s Navy to Thwart Russia
summary: The U.S. is channeling support to Ukraine’s navy to help counter Russian efforts to choke Kiev’s economy and destabilize its pro-Western government by blocking port access.

headline: Airbnb Wants to Be a Contender
summary: Airbnb seems to be bulking up for a fight against major online travel agents while still flying under the public radar.

headline: Is Your ETF Conflicted?
summary: How to tell if your exchange-traded fund is subject to potential conflicts of interest.

headline: Alibaba’s Latest Deal Should Deliver the Goods
summary: Alibaba’s latest deal shows how ensuring fast and reliable delivery is getting ever more important for the Chinese e-commerce giant.

headline: Index Futures Set to Further Pry Open Chinese Markets
summary: Global investors could soon have an easier way to make bets on or against China’s stock market, with Hong Kong’s exchange planning to offer futures trading tied to mainland shares.

headline: Why This Fintech Star Can’t Shake Off Short Sellers
summary: German payments company Wirecard has grown spectacularly and some expect an equally spectacular fall. The fintech star’s best defense is to explain its rise much more clearly.

headline: Turkey’s Shrinking Economy Poses a Challenge to Erdogan
summary: The Turkish economy shrank at the end of 2018 and looks set to contract further this year, presenting a challenge for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan ahead of a critical electoral test for his ruling party.

headline: China Car Sales Keep Skidding
summary: Auto sales in China continued their downhill run into February, declining for the eighth consecutive month.

headline: Bid to Lure Biotech Listings From U.S. Falls Flat
summary: Hong Kong’s stock exchange revamped its listing rules last April, allowing fledgling biotechnology companies to list before they turn a profit. It has hosted six such initial public offerings since.

headline: Ethiopian Airlines Passengers Included Humanitarians and a Nigerian Literary Star
summary: A Nigerian literary legend, a British marine conservationist and an Irish humanitarian: the list of passengers on Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302 is a testament to the unique blend of people drawn to East Africa.

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: No-Deal Brexit Could Cause Cash-Flow Problems for U.K. Suppliers
summary: European businesses are expected to press U.K. suppliers for discounts, delay payments or search for alternative sources if border delays arise as a result of Brexit.

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: ‘Extension Cord’ to Carry Green Power From Midwest to East
summary: Siemens and Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners are backing a $2.5 billion project to carry renewable electricity underground through the American heartland.

headline: Tesla’s Musk Rebuts SEC’s Motion to Hold Him in Contempt
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk pushed back against regulators, telling a federal judge he didn’t violate a fraud settlement that restricted his social-media communications and suggested the government is trying to muzzle him.

headline: What You Need to Know About Flying on a Boeing 737 MAX
summary: After the crash of Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302, the second for this type of plane in five months, here’s what we know about that jet, and what we don’t.

headline: FAA Has No Current Plans to Ground Boeing’s 737 MAX
summary: U.S. aviation regulators said they have no current plans to ground Boeing’s 737 MAX airliners following the deadly crash in Ethiopia, and expect by the end of April to mandate a software fix for an automated flight-control system that played a central role in the recent Lion Air crash of the same model.

headline: May Secures Last-Minute Concessions Ahead of Crucial Brexit Vote
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May secured concessions from the European Union over her Brexit divorce deal Monday, in a last-minute push to head off a large-scale defeat when the British Parliament votes on the agreement Tuesday.

headline: Firms to Pay $125 Million to Clients Over Fee-Disclosure Practices
summary: Almost 80 investment advisory firms agreed to pay back more than $125 million to clients who were steered into higher-cost mutual funds without being clearly told about cheaper versions.

headline: Tech Gains Lift Stock Benchmarks
summary: U.S. stocks climbed at the start of the week, powered by gains in the technology sector and signals that the U.S. and China were nearing a currency deal. But a drop in shares of Boeing hurt the Dow industrials.

headline: U.S. Tells Germany to Drop Huawei or See Intelligence Sharing Pared Back
summary: The Trump administration has told the German government it would limit the intelligence it shares with German security agencies if Berlin allows Huawei to build Germany’s next-generation mobile-internet infrastructure.

headline: A 3-D-Printed Family Home? Texas Startup Says Yes
summary: A Texas startup says it will be able to use a 3-D printer to churn out a concrete house within days by year-end, a technology that has the potential to help solve housing shortages but faces regulatory and technical hurdles.

headline: Safety Fears Put Boeing on the Defensive
summary: Boeing came under broad pressure Monday after the weekend’s fatal crash in Ethiopia, as investors and passengers joined a handful of aviation regulators expressing worry about the safety of the 737 MAX 8 jetliner.

headline: Top Oil Execs Call For Change as Climate, Technology Concerns Threaten Industry
summary: Some of the world’s top oil executives plan a call to action at a premier industry conference this week, arguing that companies need to actively address climate change and technology concerns that are scaring investors away.

headline: Nvidia to Acquire Mellanox for Roughly $7 Billion
summary: Nvidia agreed to acquire networking firm Mellanox Technologies for about $6.9 billion, its largest deal by far as it bolsters its bet on cloud computing after suffering a stinging drop in its core graphics-chips business late last year.

headline: How Aging Clothing Brands Are Trying to Look Young Again
summary: Brands such as 43-year-old Italian clothing label Paul & Shark are collaborating with more millennial-focused labels to entice a younger generation of shoppers.

headline: Please Howard, Don’t Hurt ’Em
summary: Are media pundits afraid Schultz will help re-elect Trump, or that the former Starbucks CEO will pull Democrats toward the center?

headline: Barrick Drops Newmont Bid; Both Agree to Joint Venture
summary: Barrick Gold, the world’s biggest gold miner, called off its nearly $18 billion offer for rival Newmont Mining after the two agreed to a Nevada joint venture.

headline: JPMorgan’s Own Clients Are Its Biggest ETF Buyers
summary: JPMorgan’s Japan-focused exchange-traded fund is one of the fastest ETFs ever to surpass $1 billion in assets, but its biggest buyers were JPMorgan’s clients.

headline: Smartphone Addicts’ New Tactic to Break Their Habit: Buy a Second Phone
summary: A new crop of minimalist phones, in small sizes with limited functions, have gained a following; ‘I’m not compelled to get that dopamine rush.’

headline: Why I Attended Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop Summit
summary: We asked nine attendees of Gwyneth Paltrow’s wellness conference—including Paltrow’s own mother, Blythe Danner—whether the event lived up to its $1,000 ticket.

headline: London’s Finance Industry Has Decided: Brexit Is Already a Reality
summary: Parliament votes Tuesday to ease the U.K.’s exit from the EU, but some in the financial industry haven’t waited to forge their own path—moving offices and billions of dollars to competing financial centers elsewhere in Europe.

headline: Wells Fargo Regulators Weigh Executive Shakeup as CEO Heads to Washington
summary: Wells Fargo remains at sharp odds with its government overseers. How sharp should come into focus Tuesday, when CEO Timothy Sloan appears before a House Financial Services Committee.

headline: How We Reinvestigated the ‘Serial’ Murder for HBO
summary: When two private investigators were hired to evaluate the many theories about Adnan Syed’s murder conviction—made famous by the podcast Serial and a new, four-part documentary series on HBO—they crisscrossed the globe, from the scrap yards of Baltimore to the alleyways of Seoul.

headline: The Last Days of Taliban Head Mullah Omar
summary: Mullah Mohammad Omar, the founder of the Taliban, lived in hiding near a U.S. base in southern Afghanistan until his death, according to a new research-group report that contradicts long-held theories by U.S. officials about the notorious one-eyed leader.

headline: Indonesia, China Ground Some Boeing Jets After Fatal Crash
summary: In a break with air-safety practice, Indonesia joined China in grounding Boeing 737 MAX 8 aircraft following the deadly crash of an Ethiopian Airlines jet of the same type. Boeing shares fell roughly 10% in early trading.

headline: Big Beauty Taps Black-Owned Startups’ Loyal Customers
summary: Procter & Gamble and other consumer-products conglomerates are acquiring black-owned hair- and skin-care brands, many of which have loyal followings.

headline: Bigger Than E*Trade: A Chinese Online Broker Soars
summary: Bubbly Chinese stocks are back. Almost four years after an epic boom and bust, China’s markets are on another roller-coaster ride, with shares in internet companies and brokerage houses among the most volatile.

headline: Tonight’s Dinner? In a Cooler-Sized Robot That Knows Where You Live
summary: Fast-food chains and grocery stores are teaming with big car companies and tiny startups to test the idea of autonomously shuttling food to customers. But it may be a while before meal-hauling robots become the norm.

headline: China Grounds All Boeing 737 MAX 8 Jets After Ethiopian Airlines Crash
summary: In a break with traditional air-safety practice, China ordered all of the country’s airlines to ground the Boeing 737 MAX 8 aircraft following the deadly crash of an Ethiopian Airlines jet of the same family.

headline: Ethiopian Airlines Boeing Jet Crashes En Route to Nairobi
summary: An Ethiopian Airlines Boeing 737 MAX 8 crashed en route from Addis Ababa to Nairobi, killing all 157 aboard including eight Americans and 18 Canadians and raising fresh scrutiny of the Boeing jet—a new model that was involved in another deadly crash last year.
